text:
Diogenes the Cynic was a controversial figure in Ancient Athens, known for his simple lifestyle and criticism of social values.
**The Lantern**
Diogenes is famously said to have walked through the streets of Athens in broad daylight carrying a lit lamp. When asked what he was doing, he replied, "I am just looking for a human being." He meant that he was looking for an honest man, but finding none, implying that the people around him were not truly human in the virtuous sense.
**Alexander the Great**
There is a famous account of a meeting between Diogenes and Alexander the Great. Alexander, thrilled to meet the famous philosopher, asked if there was any favour he might do for him. Diogenes replied, "Yes, stand out of my sunlight." Alexander was so struck by this, and admired Diogenes' spirit so much that he said to his followers, "But truly, if I were not Alexander, I would be Diogenes."
**Plato's Chicken**
When Plato gave the definition of man as "featherless biped," Diogenes plucked a chicken and brought it into Plato's Academy, saying, "Behold! I've brought you a man." After this incident, "with broad flat nails" was added to Plato's definition.
**Casting Away the Cup**
Diogenes believed in living in accordance with nature and rejecting all unnecessary possessions. One day, he saw a child drinking from his hands at a fountain. Diogenes immediately threw away his cup, saying, "A child has beaten me in plainness of living."
**The Tub**
He lived in a large ceramic jar (often translated as a tub) in the Metroon, near the Agora of Athens. This was to demonstrate that a man needs very little to survive and be happy.
**Insult to Logic**
When someone declared that motion is impossible (Zeno's paradox), Diogenes got up and walked around. When asked to explain his action, he said, "It is solved by walking."
**On Exile**
When someone reminded him that the people of Sinope had sentenced him to exile, he replied, "And I sentenced them to stay at home."
**Begging**
Diogenes was known to beg for his living. When asked why he begged from statues, he replied, "I am practicing being rejected."
When asking a man for money, he said, "If you have already given to others, give to me also; if not, start with me."
**Fate**
"He has the most who is most content with the least."
**On Virtue**
He used to say that he saw many people rivaling one another in the stadium, but no one in the pursuit of virtue.
